I have decided to create the Taj Mahal because it is a unique building with delicate detail and I wanted to set myself a challenge. I chose to enter in the ART: SEE THE WORLD challenge because I am fascinated in seeing the world and I love to travel, so I thought this was an appropriate challenge for me. The thing I have made can be used as a decorative piece around the house, or a piece to get motivation to travel. I made my thing all from scratch with only a picture for inspiration. At first I was not too sure if I had the right measurements for everything but after completing it I am quite happy with the outcome. Making this thing took a lot of time, patience and effort, but while it was a difficult challenge, I enjoyed making it and finding out a lot about the Taj Mahal’s history. Due to small measurement difficulties I had to redesign the main dome to make it the right shape. I started off making the model with a clear idea of what it would look like, which is why I think I didn’t have many difficulties making it.

author: romuloa123

title: This is a later version of what seems to be a revolutionary device.

description.text: I have made a quadcopter that has its own specific base that has been designed to look its part. The propellers cannot move because the design tree would not allow to have a floating piece. These are just practically for show but if there were a rotor that was able to move then it would be able to use the wind like the design requirements. I was trying to put a cool design on the base and then to insert the wings/ propellers so that I did not have to make it one whole piece. The main piece has had the lines cut through so that it appears to have a good layout. Then the curve of the base is basically a fillet that would just get over so it is rounded off for maximum effect. If this was to fly then it would be able to have a more aerodynamic structure. Beforehand I was going to make a floating version but then I decided to construct a flying option. Overall I eventually made a decision to put this design into the engineering section that would allow me to show a later version of what seems to be a major scientific advancement.

Bicycle handle bar Grips.

Equipment needed.
File or Rasp.
Sand paper.
x2 hose Clamps.
Pliers or/and E-tape.
Wood Filament or rubber PLA Filament optional. Inner dimentions of object;
Inner diameter of hole is .73"/18.6mm 1) Print the part
2) Sand and finish inside of part to fit snugly on handle bars.
3) Slide on hose clamp with tail facing towards the front tire of bike.
4) Slide Handles on to handle bars as far as they will go.
5) Slide the Hose clamps onto the small split compression teeth.
6) Fasten the hose clamp snugly. Note: you do not want to split the plastic, or wood.
7) Check to see if the handles move.
8) If they don't you are all set to bend the tail of the hose clamp tightly to its self with pliers, or use E-tape.

remixed_from.author: jamesarm97
remixed_from.title: Thumbwheel M3 with scale 0.01 mm with grip (Nut on bottom)

description.text:
This a redesigned version of James' thumbscrew http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:874155.

The piece he posted did not fit the nuts I was using so I created it to fit a nut with a 5.5 mm inscribed radius (from hexagonal flat to flat) or 6 mm circumscribed radius ( hexagonal vertex to vertex).

My printer did not provide as good a top finish as the original thing and so I made the numbers on the top protrude outward rather than cut inward.

It prints flawlessly with a 0.1 mm layer height and 15% infill on the PLA I am using. If the nut doesn't easily fit, I find placing it on a heated bed for 5 minutes at 100 degrees C and then wedging it into the soft PLA works well in fitting it in and also locking it from falling out.

Future mods include making it thinner to allow more travel on the bed height adjustment screws, and increasing the texture roughness on the barrel of the screw.

author: viva3dprt

title: Timelapse Camera Slide - Ex-3D Printer Bits
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After seeing timelapse sequences other people had created that introduced camera movement I knew I had to build a timelapse camera dolly or camera slide. I had a project to make a 3D printer which had stalled - after a fun morning dismantling it I had a fun afternoon re building it as this Camera Slide. It makes use of the same electronics and motors as used on a Reprap type of 3D printer. The coding and electronics can easily be adapted for use with any Arduino and a stepper motor driver. The STLs provided here will allow you to make a similar slide of any length you wish.

More information and the coding and electronics are detailed on my website:
http://www.techmonkeybusiness.com/timelapse-camera-slide-from-a-3d-printer.html

Now that I have a timelapse camera slide I just need to get out and about (preferably into the mountains) to make use of it. Here in windy Wellington (NZ), the clouds move so fast that timelapse photography is not needed.

March 2016 - Update
I have designed a better version. You can find that here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1419236 or if you want absolutely all the info and a few more diagrams and images, go to my website here: http://www.techmonkeybusiness.com/timelapse-camera-slide-version-2.html.

The 3D printed bits were from a grab-bag of bits from an aborted 3D Printer project. If I recall correctly they were all printed at about 15% fill, with double layers on the top and bottom surfaces and all outside perimeters being two layers thick.

Full details on the electronic circuits and Arduino code can be found on my website:
http://www.techmonkeybusiness.com/timelapse-camera-slide-from-a-3d-printer.html

The design includes some panels which can be cut from medium density fibreboard or acrylic. The TurboCAD, DWG, and DXF files that could be used for laser cutting are on my website.

The rails are 16mm OD Aluminium tube, and the drive screw is M8 threaded rod. The design is such that you can make the slide any length you like. All you will need to do is change one parameter in the Arduino code to reflect how much travel you have available.

comments.text: A while ago, on a relatively still day, I set the camera slide up on some 2m long rails and took it a nearby spurline over looking the city and let it run for about an hour.  The video can be seen here;
